markdown.label: [Experience] Gandi.net
markdown.markdown: [37m [0m Employer [32mGandi.net[0m Location [32mSan Francisco, CA[0m Dates [32mFebruary 2012 to December 2015[0m 2013-2015 [33m[1m[7mChief of counter-bullshit operations[0m A.K.A. [32m[33mDeveloper advocate[0m [33mAPI evangelist[0m [33mTechnical community manager[0m [33mChaos monkey[0m [33mEmergency PR strategist[0m [33mOpen source champion[0m [33mAutomation specialist[0m [33mSpecial projects[0m [33mQA intern[0m [33mWorkshop administrator[0m [33mSwag dealer[0m[0m 2012-2013 [33m[1m[7mLevel 1 Support Agent[0m A.K.A. [32m[33mSupport ticket answerer person[0m [33mDocumentation tweaker[0m [33mBug hunter[0m [33mTwitter person[0m [33mQuestion asker[0m[0m

markdown.label: Details
markdown.markdown:
[37m [0m
I interacted with various tech communities, online and at industry events, connecting with developers and helping them make the most of Gandi's domain, SSL and hosting APIs.
I was the primary technical contact for Gandi resellers in the U.S., escalating to the CTO where appropriate.
Internally, I worked with engineers, product managers and support to improve Gandi's APIs, web interface, documentation and open source presence based on feedback collected from the community.
I shaped much of Gandi's voice via blog posts, newsletters and social media interactions. I created, edited and localized a wide variety of technical documentation, emergency communications and product communications.
I guided and managed Gandi's supported initiatives and open source projects, organizing various campaigns and partnerships for our mutual benefit.
I tested and documented a huge number of Gandi's products and features.
Mostly: I was ready for anything, which usually happened at least twice a week.

markdown.label: TL;DR
markdown.markdown:
[37m [0m My original role at Gandi was entry-level support: troubleshooting and explaining issues relating to domain names, DNS, SSL certs and basic hosting.
My curiosity and interest in this role led me to specialize in more technical hosting issues, while helping to hire, train and mentor new employees, edit blog posts, and generally pitch in anywhere I could be helpful.
This versatility led me to be promoted to a so-called Community Manager role in our new San Francisco office.
From the time I was hired (near the beginning of Gandi's expansion into the U.S.) to the time I left, I had played a role in nearly every aspect of our growth in the United States.
